title: Why are movie studios reluctant to produce fresh ideas? - Quora

response.answer_text: They are not. The premise of your question and the logic behind the premise are flawed. Just because many films are not “fresh” ideas does not imply reluctance to produce films that are based on “fresh” ideas. Of the 6–700 films released in the average year, just a little fewer than half of them are entirely new IP. That represent perhaps a billion dollars or more of production money going to “fresh” ideas from studios annually. Not really indicative of a great reluctance.

New ideas are not guaranteed to make money. A new idea, if it catches on, is likely to make more money but that’s a big ‘if.’ Believe it or not Star Wars was a huge gamble in 1977 which is why the only bankable star was the has-been Alec Guinness. Remakes are likely to retain their initial audience and pick up more by word-of-mouth. Sad but true.
